vectorData.altText: 13. Identify the histological features indicated by B. Be specific.
That's right!  Dendrites are highly branched structures that receive signals from presynaptic nerve terminals and relay information toward the cell body.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

Neurons function in information transfer & processing. There are a variety of different structurally and functionally distinct types of neurons, but their basic mechanism of signaling is constant, whether communicating visual input or controlling the mvt of a muscle.
Within a neuron, communication occurs unidirectionally, 
Neurons are polarized; their two ends differ in structure and fxn.
Dendrites: input, receptive
graded electrical signals code the strength of stimulus
usually numerous, highly branched, short
Cell body (soma): input
genetic and metabolic centre of cell
Axon (nerve fibre):  integration, output
Begins at the axon hillock (E)
fixed amplitude APs start at the initial segment
usually one axon / cell; permit unidirectional flow of info
vary greatly in length, so might fxn. locally or distantly
may be myelinated; may be unmyelinated
may branch distally, forming axon collaterals; end as:
Synaptic terminals:
chemical transfer of information
target cell type varies (other neuron, muscle, gland)
the part of the axon that is the most excitable, and therefore will most easily convert a graded signal into an action potential
